status_message:
Thankfully, we have not seen any flooding or significant weather-related problems on the Forty Acres.

We are working closely with local and state emergency agencies to prepare and are also making contingency plans in case any of our outdoor, pre-semester events need to be moved indoors.

Classes are scheduled to start Wednesday. But we want to reiterate that students and families planning to come to campus should put their safety first when making travel decisions and that the university will accommodate students who are not able to be here because of weather-related issues. 

We are also available to assist students who live off campus and are concerned about flooding in their residences. They should call Student Emergency Services at 512-471-5017.

More information is available at emergency.utexas.edu.
Our hearts are heavy today as we see the destruction in South Texas. We send positive thoughts to our fellow Texans affected by #HurricaneHarvey

We continue to monitor Hurricane Harvey's conditions closely. So far, there are no reports of flooding or danger around campus, but we are prepared to take immediate action if that changes. We will continue to provide updates throughout the day.

â€”â€” UPDATE | 9 p.m. | Friday, August 25 â€”â€”

Dear UT Community, 

University officials continue to monitor the weather and travel conditions as Hurricane Harvey, now a Category 4 hurricane, makes landfall and approaches Central Texas.

We are collaborating with the City of Austin and state emergency agencies and will provide updates throughout the weekend on weather and safety issues via text (for urgent matters) and email, and through traditional and social media.

Mooov-In continues, and nearly 5,000 residents had checked in to residence halls as of 7 p.m. Students who arrive on campus have been directed to check in at their residence halls instead of going to UFCU Disch-Falk Field, where the main Mooov-In event had been taking place.

As we indicated in our previous email to the campus community, students and families planning to come to campus during the weekend should put their safety first when making travel decisions. For those students who are unable to get to campus in time for class because of the weather, we will work to accommodate their needs in residence halls and classrooms.

As a reminder, for up-to-the-minute information, anyone can sign up for text updates by texting to the keyword UTMOVE to 888-777. These text updates are specifically for information this weekend and are offered in addition to the universityâ€™s urgent alert system, which is always in effect.

â€”â€”â€”â€” ORIGINAL POST â€”â€”â€”â€” 

As Hurricane Harvey moves across Texas and approaches Austin, the university is monitoring the weather and travel conditions, working to ensure the safety of all of our students, employees and visitors and assessing whether any changes are required in university functions or schedules.

University officials are speaking regularly with the City of Austin and state emergency agencies to prepare for the effects of the hurricane. The university will provide updates throughout the weekend on any weather and safety issues via text (for urgent matters) and email, through traditional and social media, and on this site (https://emergency.utexas.edu/).

TEXT UPDATES

The university is making information about the weather and its impact on students, university operations and Mooov-In available throughout the weekend via text updates.

For up-to-the-minute information, anyone can sign up for text updates by texting to the keyword UTMOVE to 888-777. A response message will be sent back immediately.

These text updates are specifically for information this weekend and are in addition to the universityâ€™s urgent alert system which is always in effect.

SOCIAL MEDIA UPDATES

The university will provide updates over the weekend via the following social media channels.
Safety and weather:
The University of Texas at Austin Police Department (UTPD)
UTAustinPolice on Twitter

Housing and Food Services:
UT Housing and Food
UTHousing on Twitter

General UT accounts:
The University of Texas at Austin
UTAustin on Twitter Twitter

Parking and Transportation Services:
UTAustinParking Twitter

PARKING

To help the campus community protect their assets, Parking and Transportation Services (PTS) is doing the following:

1. Opening all garage entrances and exits at 5 p.m. this afternoon (Friday, August 25), with the exception of the Conference Center and Health Center Garages. 
- Students are encouraged to park in garages instead of on the street or in open lots.
- Garages will be open at no charge through 10 am on Monday, August 28th. Vehicles that parked in the garages must be out by that time to avoid parking fees.
- It is recommended that vehicles are parked on levels 2 or higher.

2. Recommending during this weather system that campus avoid parking on San Jacinto Boulevard, 24th Street, and 21st Street near Waller Creek as these areas can be affected by flash flooding

3. Raising and locking west elevators of San Jacinto Garage and the SE elevator at Trinity Garage on a higher floor to prevent cabs entering a flooded area starting at 4:45 pm today (8/25/17). 

If the situation changes with Hurricane Harvey and parking, PTS will send out notification if the above action plan is extended. 

MOOOV-IN

Mooov-In has accelerated and many students have already checked in to their residence halls, some ahead of schedule. Two-thirds of residents are expected to be checked in by tonight (8/25/17).

Centralized check in for Mooov-In on Saturday, August 26 will no longer be at UFCU Disch-Falk Field. Students and their families will check in at various residence hall locations.

Creekside is the only residence hall that could be threatened due to flooding and could possibly be evacuated if conditions warrant. Contingency plans are in place to move those students to supplemental housing and lounges at residence halls if necessary.

If flooding happened at San Jacinto Residence Hall, it would only affect the first floor which has meeting rooms and food service. Residents would not have to change location.

Students and families planning to come to campus today or over the next few days should put their own safety first when making travel decisions. For those students who are unable to get to campus in time for class because of the weather, the university will work to accommodate their needs both in the residence halls and in the classroom and will provide further information as we approach Wednesdayâ€™s start of the academic year.

The Mooov-In website will continue to be updated with new information for students and their families: http://housing.utexas.edu/future/mooov-in-before-arrive

https://emergency.utexas.edu/
link_name: Home | Emergency Use Website |The University of Texas at Austin

link_name: Update on Campus Tragedy | Office of the President

status_message:
UPDATE 9:45 p.m. â€” A message from President Fenves: 

Dear UT Community:

Tonight, I write to you with a very heavy heart.

As I wrote earlier, there was a horrific act of violence that took place at the center of our campus this afternoon. Four UT students were attacked. One student was killed and three other students sustained injuries. University officials have reached out to their families to provide support. Two of the victims have since been released from the hospital.

A suspect, who is also a UT student, was apprehended within minutes of the attack and is in police custody.

I ask that our entire community come together to support the victims and their families. They are suffering, and we all must be there for them. Preparations are underway for a gathering to honor the victims that will be held in the coming days.

There is a great deal of fear on campus and in our community. That fear is very understandable, especially in light of recent vandalism and threats against students. Like you, we are following the rumors and reports circulating on social media. The UT Police Department, the Austin Police Department and the Texas Department of Public Safety are continuing to investigate all reports and do not believe that there are any further threats at this time. As a precaution, law enforcement agencies â€” UTPD, APD and DPS â€” have increased patrols on campus and west of campus. As always, if you see anything suspicious please call 911.  

Many students and parents are frustrated with how long the university took to notify them of todayâ€™s attack. I understand those frustrations, and I am committed to faster notification in the future.

Classes and events will be held tomorrow. And I know that it will be a very difficult day for everyone on the Forty Acres, so please, be there for one another. The UT Counseling and Mental Health Center has extended its hours from 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. through Wednesday. For more information about student support services, click here (https://news.utexas.edu/resources-for-campus-community) 

Once again, please keep your thoughts and prayers with the victims and their families during this very difficult time.

Sincerely,

Gregory L. Fenves
President

++++++++++

Update 6:55 p.m. â€” From The University of Texas at Austin Police Department (UTPD): 

As UTPD continues to investigate today's stabbing, we want to reiterate that we do not know of any additional or ongoing threats on or near UT campus.

We continue to work closely with the Austin Police Department and the Texas Department of Public Safety to further investigate any rumors. Thus far, we have not found any of the incidents to be credible.

As an additional precaution, we have increased police patrols on campus tonight alongside both DPS and APD. These law enforcement partners have also increased patrols west of campus.

In addition, UT shuttle buses will remain in operation until 11:00 pm this evening and SUREWALK is providing transport. To use SUREWALK, call 512-232-9255 or orderasurewalk@gmail.com.

++++++++++

Update 5:30 p.m. â€” From Austin Police Department: 

Lots of rumors swirling around. Unless you hear from an official source, there are no further threats on or off UT Austin's campus at this time.

++++++++++

Update 4 p.m. â€” Here's a message from President Fenves: 

Dear UT Community,

This afternoon, there was an attack involving multiple stabbings, which led to one death and three other victims who were seriously injured. A suspect has been apprehended and is in custody. UTPD and campus security continue to evaluate the situation and at this time we do not believe there is an ongoing threat.

Due to this horrific and senseless tragedy in the heart of our campus, we are canceling all classes and scheduled events for the rest of the afternoon and evening. A number of buildings are closed or have limited access because of the ongoing investigation.

I encourage all students, staff and faculty to follow UTPD on Twitter for updates as the investigation progresses, and we will update you as more information becomes available.  Please find community among your peers and help each other. Counseling and support services are available in the Student Activity Center or by calling 512-475-6628.

There are no words to describe my sense of loss. Campus safety is our highest priority and we will investigate this tragic incident to the greatest extent possible. Our thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their families, the witnesses to the crime, and every member of Longhorn nation. We all mourn today.  

Sincerely,

Greg Fenves
President

++++++++++

Update 3:30 p.m.: 

Due to the violent attack on campus this afternoon and limited access to some buildings because of investigation, we are cancelling classes and events for the remainder of the afternoon and evening.

There is currently no ongoing threat on campus.
We are in the process of collecting more information. For safety alerts and updates, please follow UTPD on Twitter. You can expect additional information as we have it.

++++++++++

EARLIER: 

The University of Texas at Austin Police Department (UTPD) and Austin Police Department are handling an emergency situation on campus near Gregory Gym. 

The suspect is in custody, and there is no additional, immediate threat to campus. Please avoid the area.
link_name: Resources for Campus Community | UT News | The University of Texas at Austin

40 HOURS FOR THE FORTY ACRES IS BACK!

Save the date for UT Austin's 4th annual 40 Hours for the Forty Acres. 40 Hours for the Forty Acres is a university wide giving campaign designed to energize and inspire Longhorn Nation to make gifts of any size to the areas of campus they are passionate about. 

Join us on April 12 and 13! You can help educate tomorrow's leaders, support research that is working to solve global problems, and create opportunities for future Longhorns.

UPDATE: The U.S. National Weather Service (NWS) is forecasting more heavy rains later tonight. Campus Safety and Security personnel have been in discussion with city and county officials, as well as with several of the independent school districts. At this time, we have been told that county offices, and most of the Austin Independent School District, remain on a regular schedule. The City of Austin will have an early release.

The university will continue its regular schedule. Evening event organizers will notify patrons if there are cancellations. We ask that evening employees and students carefully evaluate their personal situations prior to coming to campus.  If conditions along your route are not safe for you to travel, please stay home.

Evening shift employees living in areas impacted by flooding, or who remain home because of road conditions, should contact their supervisors to inform them of their situation. Students who are unable to attend class because of the severe weather should contact their professors and instructors to discuss making up any classwork. 

Again, please stay weather aware as this situation continues. We will update you if threatening weather chances increase overnight. You can find more information here: http://utne.ws/1iqgQ82

Lights off! Tonight, the #UTTower will be dark in support of Longhorn Lights Out, a voluntary initiative demonstrating how simple, individual actions can result in significant energy savings across campus: http://utex.as/1WlZrQF #LonghornLightsOut #CampusLightsOut
link_name: Longhorn Lights Out: Tower Darkens to Promote Energy Savings

status_message:
UPDATE: The #UTAustin campus will experience storms and showers most of the day, according to the U.S. National Weather Service (NWS). While the conditions here are currently wet, and at times windy, there is no serious weather threat on the main campus at this time. As always, we ask our commuters to carefully evaluate their personal situations with regards to safety. If conditions along your route are not safe for you to travel, please stay home.

Employees who remain home because of weather should contact their supervisors to inform them of their situation. Students who are unable to attend class should contact their professors and instructors to discuss making up any classwork.

We will keep you posted as this situation progresses throughout the day. Stay safe. You can find more information here: http://utne.ws/1iqgQ82

The U.S. National Weather Service (NWS) has issued a severe thunderstorm warning for our area. At this time we ask that you stay alert and weather aware. Go here for information on how to shelter in place if we get high winds/tornado: http://utex.as/1WlEBB8
UTPD and Troy Kimmel are watching the weather closely. We will report information as needed for the campus area. Please be careful and stay tuned in. Be safe!
link_name: Tornado Watch, Flash Flood Warning in Effect for Parts of Central Texas

#TBT: Relive highlights of the Presidential Inauguration of Gregory L. Fenves last week.

In a ceremony filled with the presidential emblems, sweeping views of the Forty Acres and music from university and community ensembles, Gregory L. Fenves was formally inaugurated as the 29th president of The University of Texas at Austin on Sept. 17.

He also delivered his first-ever State of the University address, in which he laid out his vision to build on the university's excellence by more effectively merging its research and teaching missions and fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and research.

First, he invented the lithium-ion battery, which powers electronics you use everyday.
 
Now, professor John Goodenough and a team of Cockrell School of Engineering researchers are making significant advancements in the race to develop a commercially viable sodium-ion battery.

As one of the few self-sustaining athletics programs in the nation, Texas Athletics enhances the mission of the university by contributing financially to student and faculty programs and academic initiatives.

Today, more than 500 student-athletes compete in 20 sports programs where they are instilled with the passion, knowledge and character it takes to compete to win, to succeed academically, to achieve dreams and to contribute to society.

Natural structures have long inspired human innovations. The bee honeycomb structure, for example, has been applied to products as varied as car bumpers and athletic helmets to absorb impact.

The only drawback to the honeycomb has been its inability to maintain its unique structure after just one hit. The material buckles and doesn't bounce back.

To solve this problem, researchers in the Cockrell School of Engineering developed a groundbreaking honeycomb-inspired energy-absorbing structure to better withstand blunt and ballistic impact. In short, these honeycombs bounce back when other honeycombs do not.

Learn more about the UT Austin teamâ€™s research on the innovative structure: http://utex.as/1iY8fKV #WhatStartsHere
link_name: Bouncing Back and Back and Back and Back

Can mass extinctions speed up evolution? 

Using a virtual model based on real-life disasters like the one that killed off the dinosaurs, a team of computer scientists at UT Austin discovered robots evolve more quickly and efficiently after a mass extinction.

Researchers in the Cockrell School of Engineering - UT Austin  have developed a groundbreaking new energy-absorbing structure to better withstand blunt and ballistic impact. The technology, called negative stiffness (NS) honeycombs, can be integrated into car bumpers, military and athletic helmets and other protective hardware.

The technology could have major implications for the design and production of future vehicles and military gear to improve safety.

Learn more about this #WhatStartsHere innovation.
link_name: New Honeycomb-Inspired Design Delivers Superior Protection from Impact

The Texas Investment: UT Austin's economic impact on Texas 

On his Tower Talk blog, President Bill Powers shares the results of a recently completed economic study. In fiscal year 2013, human capital creation, start-up and spin-off companies, operations spending, and payroll at UT Austin, together with the spending of our students and visitors, generated $8.8 billion in added income to the Texas economy.

This constitutes a 15-to-1 return on investment by the state, and is the equivalent in economic activity of creating 133,000 jobs every year.
link_name: New study confirms huge economic impact of UT Austin

A psychology study from UT Austin sheds new light on todayâ€™s standards of beauty, attributing modern menâ€™s preferences for women with a curvy backside to prehistoric influences.

â€œWhatâ€™s fascinating about this research is that it is yet another scientific illustration of a close fit between a sex-differentiated feature of human morphology â€” in this case lumbar curvature â€” and an evolved standard of attractiveness,â€ù said the studyâ€™s co-author David Buss, a UT Austin psychology professor. â€œThis adds to a growing body of evidence that beauty is not entirely arbitrary, or â€˜in the eyes of the beholderâ€™ as many in mainstream social science believed, but rather has a coherent adaptive logic.â€ù

status_message:
Update 3/5/15, 6:18 a.m.: #UTAustin still set to open at 1 PM, classes to start at 2 PM. Weather conditions will be clearer, UT remains focused on academics.

The national weather service indicates conditions will be improving this morning and into the afternoon.

Based on this information, the university maintains its decision to reopen at 1 p.m. with classes beginning at 2 p.m. today, Thursday, March 5. Shuttles will begin operating at 12:45 p.m.

Employees and students: We ask that you continue to evaluate your personal situation carefully. Should you determine that is unsafe for you to travel, please contact your supervisor or faculty to inform them of your situation.

Due to potential winter weather, The University of Texas at Austin will officially close at 9:30 p.m. Wednesday, March 4, 2015 and delay opening until 1 p.m. Thursday, March 5, 2015. Classes will begin at 2 p.m. Thursday. Shuttle buses will begin operating at 12:45 p.m.

Those classes that are scheduled to already be under way at 2 p.m. will be cancelled or have a delayed start time. Students should follow faculty instructions with regard to those class start times.

The university will continue to monitor the situation through the morning. As the situation progresses, updates specific to closure and reopening will be available through local media, the university's Facebook page and Twitter feed, the emergency web page (www.utexas.edu/emergency), and by calling the university's emergency information number, 512-232-9999.

Before traveling to campus, carefully assess your personal safety. If conditions are not safe for you to travel, please stay home.

In the early 1930s the Regents of The University of Texas hired Paul Philippe Cret (1876-1945) as the university's supervising architect and commissioned him to draw up a general plan for the campus. Of Cretâ€™s multiple proposed designs the Regents chose a large, Mediterranean-influenced Beaux-Arts building topped by a 31-story tower. The great tower, the only structure that competed with the dome of the State Capitol on the Austin skyline, became the centerpiece of the campus and formed, in Cret's words, "the image carried in our memory when we think of the place."

â€œWe are so fortunate to have the Paul Cret Collection of design drawings for his University of Texas Buildings in the Alexander Architectural Archive,â€ù says Nancy Sparrow, curatorial assistant. â€œYou could say we have both the dream and the reality.â€ù

Vincent R. DiNino, Director of Bands Emeritus, dies at 95 -- http://ow.ly/Blxy4 

The Showband of the Southwestâ€™s first full-time director passed away late Tuesday. DiNino, known to many as â€œMr. Dâ€ù, arrived at the university in 1955. He was Director of the Longhorn Band from 1955-1975 and Director of University Bands from 1969 until his retirement in 1985. During his time as director, he took the an all-male, all-white band and fully integrated the band, opening it to all students.  

Big Bertha, the â€œSweetheart of the Longhorn Band,â€ù arrived during his first year at UT. DiNino is known for March Grandioso, a trademark fight song that was introduced in 1955, and later for Wabash Cannonball. Originally introduced in 1970, Wabash Cannonball was Coach Darrel K Royalâ€™s favorite tune, and so DiNino had the band play it between the third and fourth quarters of every football game as a salute to Coach Royal who had just won his third national championship. Mr. D also chose the bandâ€™s famous cowboy-style uniforms. 

â€œWe've lost a University of Texas legend, a dear friend to many, and a mentor to generations of Longhorn Band alumni.  Vince DiNino built an athletic band program worthy of the University's accomplishments on the playing fields.â€ù â€“ Douglas Dempster, dean, College of Fine Arts 

â€œVincent R. DiNino is to the Longhorn Band what Darrell K Royal is to UT Football!â€ù â€“ Robert Carnochan, director, Longhorn Band

Visit our Storify page for tributes -- http://ow.ly/Blu9r  [Image: Jerry Hayes]

For the fifth year in a row, UT McCombs School of Business earned first place in all three of the annual Public Accounting Report rankings: undergraduate, master's, and doctoral.

Undergraduate: For 23 years in a row, McCombs has placed first or second in this ranking. 

Master's: McCombs has led the nation at the master's level in 20 out of the past 21 surveys.

Doctoral: McCombs has landed among the top four doctoral programs since 1994, and has now taken the No. 1 spot six years in a row, and 11 times over the last 13 years.

Beginning on Sept. 1, Young will serve as development officer for program alumni relations. He will help raise money to support UT Division of Diversity and Community Engagement (DDCE) programs that address the educational challenges of first-generation college students and students from low-income backgrounds.

These programs include the Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence, which is part of the universityâ€™s four-year graduation initiative; UT Elementary School; the University Interscholastic League (UIL); and the UT-University Charter School, which has units throughout the state.

Men often don't express depression in ways traditionally used to diagnose the problem. They don't cry or have weight or sleeping problems. Instead, they have what experts increasingly recognize as "masked" or "male-type" depression.

Aaron B. Rochlen, UT professor and training director of the counseling psychology program, writes it is time to "unmask" depression in this Huffington Post op-ed.
link_name: Robin Williams' Death: It's Time to Unmask "Masked" Depression

Celebrating Dr. Hans Mark as a Champion of Technological Superiority

Tonight, UT Aerospace Engineering & Engineering Mechanics celebrates this Longhorn Legend.

Mark served as University of Texas Chancellor, the Director of NASAâ€™s Ames Research Center, the Director of the National Reconnaissance Office, the Secretary of the United States Air Force, Deputy Administrator of NASA and Director of Defense Research and Engineering. He was in mission control for the first moon landing and first space shuttle launch, led teams that developed aircraft and space probes, pushed President Reagan to adopt the Space Station program, and is pushing to this day for a manned mission to Mars. -- http://ow.ly/xKjJA

Perhaps you've heard that some maroon-colored bluebonnets have mysteriously appeared on the Forty Acres. The flowers grew from seed bred at Texas A&M University, leading to speculation they were planted as a prank, though there is no evidence to support this.

Don't worry: there are no plans to pull up the Aggie-colored wildflowers.

In fact, UT Austin President Bill Powers had a positive take on the flowersâ€™ presence.

"We donâ€™t know for sure where they came from," Powers told KUT Austin radio earlier this week. â€œIf itâ€™s the work of some Aggies, hats off to them, itâ€™s kind of clever. You know anyone wearing maroon would love to wake up and be in a better place.â€ù

A little personal diplomacy from President Carter went a long way in the Camp David Peace Accords in September 1978. He shared this memory at the #CivilRightsSummit Tuesday. Tune in today at 12:35 for Day 2.  http://ow.ly/vBzVX

Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin asked President Carter to sign a photo of President Carter, Egypt's President Sadat and Prime Minister Begin for his grandchildren. On the last day of the Peace Accords, Carter knocked on Begin's cabin door and delivered the photos, addressed personally to each one of Begin's grandchildren. The two leaders were both moved to tears.

UPDATE: UT Austin Closed, Classes Canceled All Day

Jan. 28, 2014

AUSTIN, Texas â€” Due to ongoing, dangerous road conditions, The University of Texas at Austin will be closed for business and all classes will be canceled for the remainder of the day today, Tuesday, Jan. 28. Weather permitting, events that are scheduled for tonight may still take place. Please check individual event websites for that information.

Individual buildings will remain open for those who are already on campus and Capital Metro shuttles will continue to operate, though with weather-related delays.

Decisions about campus delays and closures are made based on the best available information that university officials have at the time. Weather forecasts, road conditions and law enforcement warnings have changed throughout the morning, requiring UT Austin to revise its schedule to most effectively protect our students and employees. http://ow.ly/t2lYK

Update

Due to worsening road and weather conditions, The University of Texas at Austin will be closed until noon today. 

Students, faculty and staff who are already on campus or on their way to campus will still be able to enter their offices or classrooms even before the university is officially open for operations. They should make a personal decision on what is best for their safety. 

Decisions about delays and closure are made based on the best available information officials have at the time. At 3:00 AM, the forecast and predictions indicated a safe opening. Weather conditions have changed, and we are now delaying campus opening to promote the safety of staff, faculty and students.

The University of Texas at Austin is open for normal operations.

[WATCH] http://youtu.be/v4q898h05HQ

Today marks the 50th anniversary of President John F. Kennedyâ€˜s assassination in Dallas, a tragedy that still haunts the city. Read an excerpt from journalism professor Bill Minutaglio's book "Dallas 1963" and see archival JFK photographs.

The Austin Speech JFK Never Got to Make, with a Nod to UT Football

On Nov. 22, 1963, President John F. Kennedy was scheduled for two appearances in Austin after his visit to Dallas. These are the remarks prepared for him, mentioning the #1-ranked Texas Longhorn football team and the enormously popular Coach Darrell Royal. It begins:

"I'm particularly proud to be here in Texas at the home of the great University of Texas, the number one football team in the nation."

The remarks, written by staffers in Gov. John Connally's office, are part of Connally press secretary Julian Read's archive at UT's Dolph Briscoe Center for American History. Readâ€™s book "JFKâ€™S Final Hours in Texas" is an eyewitness account of the assassination.

See more archival JFK photographs: http://ow.ly/r3whT

For senior citizens fighting depression, it can be difficult to find treatment that addresses mobility and privacy concerns. "Whatâ€™s exciting about this new work is that it goes straight to the source in characterizing geographic areas directly in terms of the personality traits that are more prevalent in different regions,â€ù Gosling says.

Learn more about their findings: http://ow.ly/q6Yhc

You need a really big telescope...  http://ow.ly/q6wwp

UT astronomer Steven Finkelstein led a team that has discovered the most distant galaxy ever found. They found that this galaxy is seen at about 700 million years after the Big Bang, when the universe was just 5% of its current age of 13.8 billion years.

Their study results will be published Thursday in the journal Nature.

The Kniker Carillon (pronounced ku-NICK-er KAIR-uh-lon) is named after a UT Austin alumna, Hedwig Thusnelda Kniker (BA 1916, MA 1917).  When she died in 1985, she directed the executors of her estate to provide the funding necessary to complete the carillon.

This Self-Guided Tour offers you a personal view of the Forty Acres. Youâ€™ll get a little bit of history, a little bit of insight, and a lot of firsthand views of campus buildings, common areas, and art and architecture.

In 1839 the Congress of the Republic of Texas ordered that a site be set aside to meet the stateâ€™s higher education needs. Some 40 years later the state legislature called for the establishment of â€œa university of the first classâ€ù that would be located in Austin. 

In November of 1882, construction began on the original Main Building, and less than one year later, on Sept. 15, 1883, the university was opened with one building, six schools, a law department, eight professors, a proctor and 221 students. Today, the university is home to about 51,000 students, 17 colleges and schools, more than 100 undergraduate and 170 graduate degree programs, and more than 3,000 faculty. 

The universityâ€™s main campus began on forty acres set aside on College Hill when Austin became the state capital. Today the main campus covers more than 350 acres, but many people refer to it as â€œthe Forty Acres.â€ù This Self-Guided Tour offers you a personal view of the Forty Acres. Youâ€™ll get a little bit of history, a little bit of insight, and a lot of firsthand views of campus buildings, common areas, and art and architecture.

UT Police Chief: Threat was given for several buildings. Started working with several agencies on phone number and began working.
Pres. Powers: We are confident that campus is safe. This was a joint effort and blessed with local, state, federal officials help.
Pres. Powers: We had a threat of explosives of campus. This threat was given for later in the morning. We thought prudent to clear bldgs.
We will share updates from the press conference.  Press conference to begin soon with President Powers and others.

Update at 11:38 a.m. CT:

All activities except classes will resume at 5 p.m. Buildings may be reentered at noon. 

Today's classes are cancelled.

Update at 10:45 a.m. CT:

Time specified in the phone threat has passed but we have not yet cleared all buildings.  A decision to resume operations, including classes, will come shortly.

Update:

Buildings are being checked and cleared. Stay away from buildings. No decision yet on afternoon classes and activities. 

Next update coming at 10:45 a.m.

Evacuation due to threats on campus.  Immediately evacuate all buildings. Get as far away from buildings as possible.

More to come.

UT Olympians have now won nine medals in the summer games. That's more than 56 countries!

Saving the Delta

In the past century, the Mississippi Delta has shrunk by about a quarter, an area roughly the size of Delaware. And a bit more land slips away each day. But recent research from the UT Jackson School of Geosciences is generating new optimism about saving the delta from erosion. -- http://ow.ly/cLU4P

Longhorns in London: Leonel Manzano wins silver in the Men's 1500m Final!

Manzano is the first American to medal in the 1500 at the Olympics since the 1968 games. (Photo by Quinn Rooney/Getty Images)

Schedule: http://ow.ly/cJgFH

Making Stars: UT astronomer Don Winget

[WATCH] Winget and studio art major Leah Flippen talk about the machine, the painting, and the interplay between science and art. http://youtu.be/cDGGRCmHdWA

Winget has been using the Z Machine, the world's largest x-ray generator, to create white dwarf "star stuff" here on earth. When the Z Machine fires, it releases more than six times the energy of all the power plants on Earth combined. 

Image courtesy of Sandia National Laboratories.

Howdy! Do you speak Texan?

As part of the Texas English Project, linguist Lars Hinrichs and his team of student researchers are collecting dozens of interviews with native Texans and documenting the factors that influence how they speak. According to their findings, the local dialect is becoming more of a choice rather than a function of place.

http://www.utexas.edu/know/2012/05/07/texas_twang/

status_message: Scary good Q&A with Associate Professor Joshua Gunn on his paranormal interests. Happy Halloween!

School of Nursing students provide care to the "Wicked Witch" during a Halloween "Hospital of Horrors" hosted by the school's Simulation Lab.

The Simulation Lab provides an environment for students to practice and demonstrate nursing skills. Students learn psychomotor, physical assessment and critical thinking skills necessary for clinical performance. Students have hands-on practice with the equipment and techniques they will need for the practice setting.

The Sim Lab has four patient bays equipped as "real world" hospital rooms, and students practice skills and acquire new knowledge using high-fidelity mannequins which can be programmed to bleed, respirate, have seizures, go into cardiac arrest, bleed out and even give birth.

Photo: Peter Hancock

Clinical Instructor Judy Flanagan (behind the mask) assists a School of Nursing student in bringing "Sleeping Beauty" back to life during a Halloween "Hospital of Horrors" hosted by the school's Simulation Lab.

The Simulation Lab provides an environment for students to practice and demonstrate nursing skills. Students learn psychomotor, physical assessment and critical thinking skills necessary for clinical performance. Students have hands-on practice with the equipment and techniques they will need for the practice setting.

The Sim Lab has four patient bays equipped as "real world" hospital rooms, and students practice skills and acquire new knowledge using high-fidelity mannequins which can be programmed to bleed, respirate, have seizures, go into cardiac arrest, bleed out and even give birth.

Photo: Peter Hancock

Today's stargazing tip from StarDate: The Beehive, a star cluster in the constellation Cancer, appears almost directly overhead in late evening. The cluster is about 500 light-years from Earth. To the unaided eye it looks like a faint smudge of light, but binoculars reveal dozens of stars.

status_message: An intrepid staffer at the PCL photographed students' doodles on the library's whiteboards during the weeks before finals. This is what he saw ...

Stemming from her childhood dream of becoming an astronaut, Lara Eakins pursued a degree in astronomy from UT. Today Eakins works in the Department of Astronomy in the College of Natural Sciences, where for nearly 15 years, she has helped support undergraduate education, conduct public outreach and operate a "fairly big, sizable telescope" at Robert Lee Moore Hall. "You know, this is actually kind of cool," she said. "I get to do this. I get paid to do this!"

So whether it's hosting star parties, fielding media calls or working with professors to develop course materials, no two days are ever the same for Eakins.

To view more audio slideshows featuring university staff go to: http://www.utexas.edu/know/2010/05/06/keys/.

status_message: Before the Longhorns and Aggies tear it up on the football field tomorrow, see how the two universities share common goals for education, research and business innovation in Texas.

Santos Rodriguez likes working with his hands: tearing things apart and putting them back together.

As a senior landscape technician with Facilities Services doing small engine repairs on lawn mowers, weed eaters and the like, Rodriguez said "it's pretty unique that I am able to do this."

At about age 11, Rodriguez was diagnosed with Behcet's syndrome affecting the use of his legs and resulting in the loss of his vision.

"I had to show a lot of people that I was able to do [mechanic work], despite being blind," he said. Now for more than 32 years, Rodriguez has been fixing, repairing and working with campus landscaping crews to make sure their equipment is in top working condition.

View another audio slideshow featuring university staff at: http://www.utexas.edu/know/2010/05/04/hitting-the-high-notes/.
link_name: In good hands with Santos Rodriguez

status_message: Snow in Austin? No one's going to believe us unless we provide photographic evidence. We want to see photos and videos of your snow day at The University of Texas at Austin. Don't wait until all the snow melts!
Weather concerns cause delayed opening. The university will open at 10 a.m. on Wednesday, Feb. 24 due to anticipated inclement weather. Stay tuned to http://www.utexas.edu/emergency/ for updates.

status_message:
New in Know: Faces of the West Mall: A series of stunning black-and-white photographs taken on five afternoons during the past four years.

The students, faculty and staff in the photos were stopped without prior arrangement on the West Mall as they were passing through, capturing their personalities exactly as they are. They are a sample of the richness and variety of the people who create a community at The University of Texas at Austin.
link_name: Faces of the West Mall Â« Know

status_message:
Do you want to unravel scientific mysteries, unleash creative energies and uncover the realms of discovery that are a part of everyday life at The University of Texas at Austin?

If so, mark your calendar for Saturday, March 6, and join the university for Explore UT, "The Biggest Open House in Texas." You can even plan and then print your schedule of activities in advance for a day of adventure on campus.

Why do only about half of newly hired Texas principals stay for at least three years? The latest UT home page feature story--on principal retention researchers Ed Fuller and Michelle Young at the College of Education--tackles this question. 

A Matter of Principal: Researchers untangle "why" behind exodus of principals from public schools
link_name: Researchers untangle "why" behind exodus of principals from public schools | The University of Texas

status_message: The university has a new academic department. The Department of African and African Diaspora Studies and an affiliated institute that will focus on urban policy were announced today.

Check out the Events tab for more details, and mark your calendars anew for Tuesday, Feb. 16. See you then!

Grad Students: On Sunday (Feb. 7), Graduate Studies Dean Victoria Rodriguez sent an e-mail inviting all graduate students to participate in an online survey about academic experiences, departmental climates, mental health and work-life balance. Participants will have the chance to win football tickets, Texercise passes, RecSports gift certificates, Performing Arts tickets and much more. Check your e-mail to find a link to the survey.
